claim: Of the 25 projects for which we attempted to locate shared datasets and generate a DATA score, nineteen (76%) had an overall score of 0 (Fig 1).
title: Fig 1. Total DATA scores from 25 NSF-funded projects, as located via data management plans.

Open in a new tabElement-wise DATA scores, which range from 0 to 2, were mostly clustered at either 0 or 2 (Fig 2).
title: Fig 2. Element-wise DATA scores from 25 NSF-funded projects, as located via data management plans.

claim: The exceptions were two projects that scored a 1 for Discoverable, and two other projects that had an element score of 1 for either Transparent or Actionable (Table 2; Fig 2).
title: Fig 2. Element-wise DATA scores from 25 NSF-funded projects, as located via data management plans.

claim: DATA scores for the 104 articles that we scored ranged from 0 (the minimum score) to 8 (the maximum score), though the distribution of scores was heavily skewed towards low values with 55 journal articles scoring zero (Fig 3).
title: Fig 3. Total DATA scores from 104 NSF-funded projects, as located via journal articles.

claim: Open in a new tabElement-wise DATA scores were primarily clustered around zero, as expected given the overall DATA score distribution, with slightly more than half of Discoverable and Accessible scores and about 60% of Transparent and Actionable scores ranking zero (Fig 4).
title: Fig 4. Element-wise DATA scores from 104 NSF-funded projects, as located via journal articles.

claim: Unlike the broad distribution that we observed in the DATA scores associated with journal articles (Fig 3), which indicates variable levels of data sharing effectiveness, we found that project-level datasets were either not shared (DATA = 0; 76% of projects) or were shared fairly effectively (Fig 1).
title: Fig 3. Total DATA scores from 104 NSF-funded projects, as located via journal articles.
